instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
Hi,

I have here an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> where the left USB-C ports are not recogizing any peripherals - charging is working - right side no issues.

Could it be that the THB IC is damaged or corroded? (Should I reflow the IC?)

Note: The MacBook was water damaged in that area, [MEDIA=imgur]a/mmiaETv[/MEDIA] (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> was bad)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
Left side USB devices are powered from L3500.
Do you get voltage there?
Test connecting an USB device, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
No voltage on L3500 (<SIGNAL>P5VUSBC_X_LL</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>P5VUSBC_X_R</SIGNAL>) - USB device is plugged in.
5.2V on LB700 (<SIGNAL>P5VUSBC_T_LL</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>P5VUSBC_T_R</SIGNAL>) - USB device is plugged in.

Note: <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> is getting 5.2V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_USBC_X_VCC</SIGNAL>, so maybe <CHIP>U3500</CHIP> is bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
LB700 is for right USB ports!
Did you check L3500 connecting an USB device on left side!

These chips fail a lot.
<CHIP>U3500</CHIP> gets 5V on both 19 & 20 pins?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
Yes 5.2V on both pins.

I have removed L3500 and found a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4_X_USBC</SIGNAL>, removed the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> ... short is still present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
threads.message:
You can inject voltage to find the culprit.
Should be one of the filter caps, near <RESISTOR>R3530</RESISTOR>; if you already removed both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) - Booting successfull - Left USB-C ports issue
